channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: In a Memoir Draft, Changpeng Zhao of Binance Details the Talks Leading to His Prison Time
item.description: In a draft of his memoir, Changpeng Zhao, the founder of Binance, laid out the secret negotiations that led to his imprisonment and a run-in with ICE.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Mattathias Schwartz
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: Binance’s founder, Changpeng Zhao, outside federal court in Seattle in 2024 at his sentencing for violating an anti-money-laundering law.

item.title: Silicon Valley Rallies Behind Anthropic in A.I. Clash With Trump
item.description: Actions by the president and the Pentagon appeared to drive a wedge between Washington and the tech industry, whose leaders and workers spoke out for the start-up.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel, Cade Metz and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pentagon underestimated how strongly Anthropic felt, current and former defense officials said.

item.title: Pentagon-Anthropic Standoff Is a Decisive Moment for How A.I. Will Be Used in War
item.description: The Pentagon’s contract dispute with Anthropic is part of a wider clash about the use of artificial intelligence for national security and who decides on any safeguards.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: The Pentagon has said that a private contractor cannot decide how its tools will be lawfully used for national security.

item.title: Elon Musk’s Secret Web of Companies in Texas
item.description: The megabillionaire was tied to about 90 companies in the state, which he uses for everything from paying nannies to buying land to supporting Donald Trump’s re-election, according to a Times examination.
item.dc:creator: Kirsten Grind, Susanne Craig, Alex Klavens and Leo Dominguez
item.media:credit: Jordan Vonderhaar for The New York Times

item.title: At the Pentagon, OpenAI is In and Anthropic Is Out
item.description: It’s been a crazy 48 hours in the A.I. industry.
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Whitney Jones, Rachel Cohn, Vjeran Pavic, Katie McMurran, Dan Powell and Alyssa Moxley
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photos: Thea Traff for The New York Times, Kevin Wolf/AP

item.title: The British Watch Brand Apiar Goes Beyond Traditional Constraints
item.description: The tech-focused leaders of the British brand Apiar aim to stretch beyond watchmaking’s traditional material and manufacturing constraints.
item.dc:creator: Thor Svaboe
item.media:credit: Jeremie Souteyrat for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sam White, right, said that he and Matt Oosthuizen were childhood friends who met “on the rugby pitch during the first week of secondary school.” Together, they founded Apiar in 2023.

item.title: OpenAI Reaches A.I. Agreement With Defense Dept. After Anthropic Clash
item.description: The deal came hours after President Trump had ordered federal agencies to stop using artificial intelligence technology made by Anthropic, an OpenAI rival.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Mike Kai Chen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sam Altman of OpenAI, which reached an agreement with the Department of Defense on A.I. on classified systems on Friday.

item.title: Instagram to Alert Parents to Teens’ Self-Harm Searches
item.description: Parents will receive notifications if a child has used the platform repeatedly to search for terms related to suicide or self-harm, but users must opt in to get them.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:credit: Dado Ruvic/Reuters
item.media:description: Meta, which owns Instagram, is promoting the parental alerts about searches for harmful content as it is on trial in two states over claims that its platforms are addictive and have harmed young users.

item.title: Is A.I. Eating the Labor Market? + The Latest on the Pentagon, OpenClaw and Alpha School
item.description: “I think the mere fact that the markets can move so much, based on almost nothing, underscores how high anxiety is right now.”
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Whitney Jones, Rachel Cohn, Vjeran Pavic, Katie McMurran, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Rowan Niemisto, Diane Wong and Leah Shaw Dameron
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photos: Getty Images (laptop); Getty Images (head)

item.title: A World Where All Is Free? That’s Elon Musk’s Theory of ‘Sustainable Abundance.’
item.description: The Tesla and SpaceX chief has told his followers that they will live in a world where robots will take care of every need and people do not have to work, in what has become his latest slogan.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: Brandon Celi

item.title: South Korea Clears Way for Google Maps to Fully Operate
item.description: South Korea approved Google’s request to export detailed map data, reversing a longstanding restriction that made the tool largely nonfunctional.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Kim Hong-Ji/Reuters
item.media:description: Unlike in most countries, Google Maps has not provided real-time driving or walking directions in South Korea.

item.title: India Built the World’s Back Office. A.I. Is Starting to Shrink It.
item.description: Artificial intelligence promises to automate the white-collar work that made India a tech powerhouse. The country is racing to adapt before it’s too late.
item.dc:creator: Steven Lee Myers, Paul Mozur and Saumya Khandelwal
item.media:description: Hunar.AI is offering companies bespoke A.I. voice agents that steer job applicants through virtually every step of the hiring process.

item.title: Google Workers Seek ‘Red Lines’ on Military A.I., Echoing Anthropic
item.description: More than 100 Google A.I. employees sent a letter to Jeff Dean, a chief scientist, opposing Gemini’s use for U.S. surveillance and some autonomous weapons.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Elijah Nouvelage/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Jeff Dean, the chief scientist of Google DeepMind, Google’s artificial intelligence division, at a company event in 2018.

item.title: Block Cuts 40% of Its Work Force Because of Its Embrace of A.I.
item.description: About 4,000 workers will lose their jobs as the payments company does more work with new artificial intelligence tools, its top executive said.
item.dc:creator: Natallie Rocha
item.media:credit: Koshiro K/Alamy
item.media:description: Jack Dorsey, Block’s top executive, attributed job cuts to his company’s embrace of A.I.

item.title: Anthropic Says It Cannot ‘Accede’ to Pentagon in Talks Over A.I.
item.description: Anthropic said it was standing firm on not having its A.I. used in certain scenarios by the Pentagon, which has imposed a Friday deadline on the company to give unfettered access to its technology.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: “We cannot in good conscience accede to their request,” Dario Amodei, chief executive of Anthropic, said in a statement.

item.title: In Landmark Trial, Plaintiff Says Social Media Harm Started at Age 6
item.description: The plaintiff, a 20-year-old identified only as K.G.M., took the stand to testify against Meta and Instagram in a bellwether case over tech addiction.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan and Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: Frederic J. Brown/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Supporters of the plaintiff outside California Superior Court of Los Angeles County during a trial over whether social media platforms were designed to be addictive to children.

item.title: They Helped Women Fight Online Abuse. They Were Barred From the U.S.
item.description: The founders of HateAid, a German human-rights group that helps victims of online attacks, were accused by the Trump administration of being part of a “global censorship-industrial complex.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano and Patrick Junker
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Patrick Junker for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna-Lena von Hodenberg, left, and Josephine Ballon, right, of the organization HateAid. The group provides legal support for victims of digital violence and engages in policy advocacy aimed at strengthening accountability for major online platforms.

item.title: A.I. Complicates Old Internet Privacy Risks
item.description: Artificial intelligence is convenient and easy to use, but you should think about what you say to the chatbots.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen
item.media:credit: Derek Abella

item.title: When Chatbots Are Used to Plan Violence, Is There a Duty to Warn?
item.description: People are revealing sensitive personal information to A.I. chatbots — including plans to commit violent acts.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill
item.media:credit: Las Vegas Metropolitan Police Department, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Matthew Livelsberger detonated explosive material in a Tesla Cybertruck in front of the Trump International Hotel in Las Vegas in January 2025. He had consulted about the plan with ChatGPT.

item.title: The A.I. Videos on Kids’ YouTube Feeds
item.description: The YouTube algorithm is pushing bizarre, often nonsensical A.I.-generated videos targeting children. Our video journalist Arijeta Lajka explains why experts say that these videos could affect their cognitive development, and how parents can identify this type of content.
item.dc:creator: Arijeta Lajka, Christina Shaman, Melanie Bencosme, June Kim and Luke Piotrowski

item.title: How A.I.-Generated Videos Are Distorting Your Child’s YouTube Feed
item.description: Experts caution that low-quality, A.I.-generated videos on YouTube geared toward children often feature conflicting information, lack plot structure and can be cognitively overwhelming — all of which could affect young children’s development.
item.dc:creator: Arijeta Lajka

item.title: A.I. Dating Apps Complicate China’s Efforts to Boost Birthrate
item.description: As China grapples with a shrinking population and historically low birthrate, people are finding romance with chatbots instead.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Murphy Zhao and Meaghan Tobin
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Lawmakers Ask Tech Companies What User Data They Provided to D.H.S.
item.description: The requests followed Times reporting that the Department of Homeland Security had sent Meta and other companies subpoenas for information on accounts that track or comment on ICE.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Bennie Thompson of Mississippi is one of three Democratic lawmakers asking tech companies about requests for user data from the Department of Homeland Security.

item.title: Nvidia’s Quarterly Profit Hits $43 Billion on Strong A.I. Chip Sales
item.description: Total profit for the fiscal year was $120 billion, the company said. Three years ago, it was just $4.4 billion.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nvidia, led by Jensen Huang, above, said quarterly revenue from its chips for A.I. data centers had risen 71 percent to $61.7 billion.

item.title: Podcasts? TV Talk Shows? Netflix Just Hopes They’re Hits.
item.description: The podcasts in the streamer’s debut crop, including “The Pete Davidson Show,” have revived metaphysical questions about the definition of the medium.
item.dc:creator: Reggie Ugwu
item.category: The White House With Michael Irvin (TV Program)

item.title: Can A.I. Detection Tools Really Spot Fake Images and Videos?
item.description: Artificial intelligence detectors are increasingly used to check the veracity of content online. We ran more than 1,000 tests and found several strengths and plenty of weaknesses.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson

item.title: Wayve, an A.I. Driverless Car Start-Up in Europe, Raises $1.2 Billion
item.description: The London-based company is building a system that uses artificial intelligence to power autonomous vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: The Asahi Shimbun, via Getty Images
item.media:description: New funding values Wayve at $8.6 billion.

item.title: Pentagon Gives Anthropic an Ultimatum Over the Company’s A.I. Model
item.description: Anthropic insists on limits on how its technology is used and could be labeled a supply chain risk if it fails to accept the military’s demands.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth summoned the chief executive of Anthropic to Washington for a meeting on Tuesday.

item.title: Senator Blumenthal Opens Inquiry Into Iran Transactions on Binance
item.description: Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut sent a letter to Binance asking about the flow of $1.7 billion from accounts on the crypto exchange to Iranian entities.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Michael Forsythe
item.category: Senate Committee on Homeland Security and Governmental Affairs
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross for The New York Times
item.media:description: In a letter to Binance, Senator Richard Blumenthal of Connecticut asked for records about the company’s dealings with two Hong Kong entities identified by the exchange’s investigators as the origin of the transfers to Iran.

item.title: How Jeffrey Epstein Ingratiated Himself With Top Microsoft Executives
item.description: For more than two decades, the convicted sex offender developed a network at the tech giant, making him privy to succession discussions and other business.
item.dc:creator: Erin Griffith and Karen Weise

item.title: More Than Half of Teens Use Chatbots for Schoolwork, Survey Finds
item.description: A new study from the Pew Research Center finds teenagers think chatbot-assisted cheating has become “a regular feature of student life.”
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Ysa Pérez for The New York Times

item.title: Intel Strikes Deal With a Chip Start-Up Its C.E.O. Invested In
item.description: A technical partnership embraces SambaNova Systems, which Intel’s chief, Lip-Bu Tan, helps lead as an investor and chairman.
item.dc:creator: Don Clark
item.media:credit: Laure Andrillon/Reuters
item.media:description: Intel said Lip-Bu Tan, its chief executive, had recused himself from talks involving SambaNova Systems.

item.title: The Looming Taiwan Chip Disaster That Silicon Valley Has Long Ignored
item.description: If China invades Taiwan and cuts off its chip exports to American companies, the tech industry and the U.S. economy would be crippled.
item.dc:creator: Tripp Mickle
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by Ben Jones; Source Photographs by Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times; Loren Elliott for The New York Times; Chang W. Lee/The New York Times

item.title: Anthropic Accuses 3 Chinese Companies of Harvesting Its Data
item.description: The San Francisco start-up claimed that DeepSeek, Moonshot and MiniMax used approximately 24,000 fraudulent accounts to train their own chatbots.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.category: Beijing Moonshot AI Technology Co Ltd
item.media:credit: Cfoto/Future Publishing, via Getty Images
item.media:description: DeepSeek is among the three Chinese start-ups accused of using data from Anthropic’s A.I. system to train their own, a process called distillation.

item.title: Pentagon Summons Anthropic Chief in Dispute Over A.I. Limits
item.description: The artificial intelligence company has demanded that some guardrails be put in place as it negotiates a contract with the Defense Department.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Sheera Frenkel
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dario Amodei, the chief executive of Anthropic, will meet with Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth at the Pentagon.

item.title: Jeff and Lauren Sánchez Bezos Will Be Honorary Chairs of the Met Gala
item.description: The news came tucked into the second page of a recent news release.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Friedman
item.media:credit: Krista Schlueter for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jeff Bezos and Lauren Sánchez Bezos at a Kering Foundation gala in New York in September.

item.title: Binance Employees Find $1.7 Billion in Crypto Was Sent to Iranian Entities
item.description: Binance pledged to crack down on crime. But internal investigators at the world’s largest crypto exchange continued to find evidence of potential legal violations on the platform.
item.dc:creator: David Yaffe-Bellany and Michael Forsythe
item.media:credit: The New York Times
item.media:description: Binance, the world’s largest venue for crypto trading, has continued to find evidence of potential legal violations on its platform, even after it pleaded guilty to breaking anti-money-laundering laws in 2023.

item.title: Backed by Anthropic, a Super PAC Group Begins an Ad Blitz in Support of A.I. Regulation
item.description: The ads by Public First Action, which started airing on Monday, are part of an escalating political war over artificial intelligence before the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anthropic’s chief executive, Dario Amodei, has pushed for regulations to create guardrails on artificial intelligence.

item.title: Need an Outfit? Pickle Clothing Rental App Helps Users Stay on Trend.
item.description: Pickle, a new peer-to-peer apparel-rental app, helps users stay on trend without having to go into debt or rely on climate-unfriendly fast fashion.
item.dc:creator: Kasia Pilat

item.title: ‘A.I. Literacy’ Is the New Drivers’ Ed at This Newark School
item.description: Teachers say they want to equip high school students to drive artificial intelligence, rather than be mere passengers steered by chatbots.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Singer
item.media:credit: Juan Arredondo for The New York Times
item.media:description: In February, North Star Academy Washington Park High School started a new A.I. class for seniors.
